Award.AwardTitle: Hybrid Nanoprobes Of Peptide-Functionalized Quantum Dots And Magnetic Nanocrystals, Interfaced Via Amphiphilic Multifunctional Polymer Ligands
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Drs. Hedi Mattoussi and Debra Fadool at the Florida State University to develop strategies to modify the surfaces of inorganic nanomaterials so that they can bind with biological systems. This will yield systems that can be used to probe specific biological species and monitor targeted biological processes without affecting the integrity of the host system. To meet this goal, new multifunctional polymers that strongly coordinate onto various nanomaterials will be designed, providing water-compatible nanoprobes that are easy to introduce into biological media/systems. The work at Florida State University provides a good example where nanotechnology is used to address important problems in biology. The present project is interdisciplinary in nature and it provides opportunities for training graduate and undergraduate students in areas such as growth and functionalization of nanocrystals, peptide design and synthesis, protein expression, and several other analytical techniques. Prof. Mattoussi and co-workers will also carry out outreach activities to undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented groups.

The project focuses on developing amphiphilic polymers as surface ligands that can tightly coordinate onto the surfaces of inorganic nanomaterials, including magnetic nanoparticles, luminescent quantum dots and gold nanoparticles. The chemical design exploits the effectiveness of the nucleophilic addition reaction to allow the simultaneous insertion of hydrophilic moieties, metal-coordinating groups and reactive functions on the same polymer platform. By combining multi-anchoring groups with hydrophilic and biologically-reactive functionalities in the same amphiphilic polymer, our design will enhance the ligand-to-nanoparticle binding, while facilitating their coupling to various target molecules. This approach will allow conjugation of QDs and magnetic nanocrystals to several target molecules, including dopamine and the margatoxin (MgTx) peptide. These resulting conjugates will be used to develop specific biosensors. In particular QD-dopamine conjugates will provide platforms that can target iron ions and cysteine-rich proteins in vitro and in cell cultures. Similarly, nanoparticle-MgTx conjugates will be used to control the current flow through the Kv1.3 potassium channels of mitral cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF grant has allowed us to develop a series of multifunctional polymers, as high affinity coatings that can sterically stabilize and easily functionalize a wide range of inorganic nanocrystals, over a wide range of conditions. These include luminescent quantum dots, magnetic iron oxide nanocrystals, as well as an array of metallic nanomaterials (Au nanoparticles, Au nanorods and Au nanoshells). The functionalized nanocrystals were exploited to probe energy transfer interactions between QDs (or AuNPs) and surface coupled dyes, using a newly developed analytical technique (sample transmitted excitation photoluminescence spectroscopy). The great control over the QD-dye conjugate configuration (valence and separation distance) allowed us to distinguish between QD PL quenching attributed to Förster dipole-dipole interactions and those involving charge transfer interactions.

We also exploited the great colloidal stability of the coated nanomaterials to probe the ability of an anticancer peptide to deliver these platforms to live cells. The peptides were covalently coupled to QDs, Au nanoparticles or Au nanorods, and the resulting conjugates were tested for promoting intracellular delivery of these nanomaterials, via a process that yields a staining distributed across the cell cytoplasm.

We recently showed that the polymer nature of our coating offers a unique advantage, by allowing the same anchoring groups (based on the lipoic acid motif) to serve the dual role of promoting strong binding onto the nanocolloids (for great stability), and at the same time providing reactive centers for easy activation, using the reliable sulfhydryl-to-maleimide reaction. This implies that simple and efficient functionalization of the nanocrystals can be achieved without introducing additional reactive groups in the coating. We have demonstrated this approach for luminescent QDs and AuNPs. We have further demonstrated the potential utility of this approach by constructing a ratiometric pH sensor.

The ideas and materials developed with the NSF support have great implications to other nanocolloids. The polymer ligands can be adapted to coat any transition metal core materials. The utility for using these and other nanocolloids in biology and medicine are highly promising.
